instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN: What is PM_PWRBTN? PM_PWRBTN refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b Board came with prior liquid damage few months ago, fixed at the time.
Customer came few days ago with not booting macbook air, i checked and noticed that there is no 5V S3 and 5v S0 also.
5v S5 present.

Was poking around and applied heat to SMC around 200c for diagnostic purpose. Mac started up, worked for 10-15 min, after cooling off same issue, so i decided to reball SMC, did it, macbook worked that evening, passed tests. In the morning i came and before calling customer decided to check it, and it is not coming on with same symptoms.
So i reballed SMC again thinking i did not good job on reballin. Same thing happened, worked same day, next day does not boot with same symptoms. 
What could be the issue?
Many thanks in advance.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Do you get amber light and steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Which is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?

Can you tell us where was the liquid spilled first time?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Amber light - yes
G3H - 8.49v
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.38v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.29v Steady
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.29v Steady

Looks like prior liquid damage was around backlight and some caps on <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSWPWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> amd check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.26v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.35v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 2.98v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.35v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 2.46v

"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>" never did this, can you explain? Sorry for lack of knowledge. 
I have to short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and measure voltage drop on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Yes, do it.
Temporary short, like pressing power button...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message: when i trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN</SIGNAL> goes from 3.35v to 0.32v.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message: Check for high pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> goes from 0.03v to 1.4v for split second
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> from 0.00v to 0.70v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> goes from 3.3v to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> stays at 3.29v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> goes from 3.3v to 0v"
Should pulse high from 0V...

Looks like all pulse, then check for pulse on all big coils; S3 and S0 voltages.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
i double checked, was measuring wrong resistor.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> goes from 0v to 1.47v
I checked at L7520 - no pulse
L7630 - no pulse

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message: Any pulse at <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> goes from 0 to 1.17v

I rechecked L7630 and L7520 for pulse, found that i was failing to short <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR> first time.

L7630 goes from 0v to 0.53v
L7520 goes from 0v to in between 0.53v to 2.2v, (could be 1.2, sometimes 1.7, sometimes 0.76)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Any pulse at CPU coils?
Also check pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> several times, to catch higher pulse.
An o-scope can catch peak pulse better.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
on L7320 highest peak is 0.32v
on L7310 highest peak is 0.31v

<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> is 0v does not pulse if trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 0v does pulse if trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> from 0v to 1.38v highest

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Make short between pins 5 & 6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and check for pulse at pin 3.
Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
"Make short between pins 5 & 6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and check for pulse at pin 3."
at pin 3 there is 0v even if i short pin 5&6.
i get constant voltage of 0.03v on Pin 2, is that ok?

Can i get info on how to do SMC bypass correctly?
I struggle to find legit source anywhere, as far as i find out yet it is done by holding the power button and inserting a magsafe cable? If yes, then nothing happens.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
"at pin 3 there is 0v even if i short pin 5&6."
Check at the time you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

You mix the things and make dificil to follow you; we need accurated infor.
In other post you said to get pulse at pin 7/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
"<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 0v does pulse if trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> from 0v to 1.38v highest"
It cannot pulse, if pin 2 doesn't pulse too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
sorry, i understood that i have to short(trigger) pin 5&6 at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and then measure pin 3.
I have to solder a wire between 5&6 and trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> while measuring pin 3? Correct?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message: Yes, you can put a solder blob between the pins.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message: highest peak i get on pin 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is 1.35v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Keep pins 5 & 6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> shorted.

Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
"Can i get info on how to do SMC bypass correctly?
I struggle to find legit source anywhere how its done, as far as i find out yet it is done by holding the power button and inserting a magsafe cable? If yes, then nothing happens. "

Highest pulse i get on <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.34v
Highest pulse i get on <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0.65v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no boot
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Be sure J6100 is clean; you can remove it, if no Medusa programmer available.

You can also try new BIOS...
